name: Explanation in Artificial Intelligence: Insights from the Social Sciences
description: This paper provides an introduction to the social science research into explanations. The author provides 4 major findings: (1) explanations are constrastive, (2) explanations are selected, (3) probabilities probably don't matter, (4) explanations are social. These fit into the general theme that explanations are -contextual-.

name: Sanity Checks for Saliency Maps
description: An important read for anyone using saliency maps. This paper proposes two experiments to determine whether saliency maps are useful: (1) model parameter randomization test compares maps from trained and untrained models, (2) data randomization test compares maps from models trained on the original dataset and models trained on the same dataset with randomized labels. They find that "some widely deployed saliency methods are independent of both the data the model was trained on, and the model parameters".

name: Explainable Deep Learning: A Field Guide for the Uninitiated
description: An in-depth description of XAI focused on technqiues for deep learning.

name: Quantifying Explainability of Saliency Methods in Deep Neural Networks
description: An analysis of how different heatmap-based saliency methods perform based on experimentation with a generated dataset.

name: Ada-SISE
description: Adaptive semantice inpute sampling for explanation.

name: ALIME
description: Autoencoder Based Approach for Local Interpretability.

name: Break Down
description: Break down plots for additive attributions.

name: CDT
description: Confident interpretation of Bayesian decision tree ensembles.

name: Conj Rules
description: Using sampling and queries to extract rules from trained neural networks.

name: DecText
description: Extracting decision trees from trained neural networks.

name: DeepLIFT
description: Deep label-specific feature learning for image annotation.

name: ExplainD
description: Explanations of evidence in additive classifiers.

name: Gibbons, et. al.
description: Explain random forest using decision tree.

name: GPDT
description: Genetic program to evolve decision trees.

name: Krishnan, et. al.
description: Extracting decision trees from trained neural networks.

name: Lei, et. al.
description: Rationalizing neural predictions with generator and encoder.

name: Lou, et. al.
description: Accurate intelligibile models with pairwise interactions.

name: MFI
description: Feature importance measure for non-linear algorithms.

name: PDA
description: Prediction Difference Analysis: Visualize deep neural network decisions.

name: POIMs
description: Positional oligomer importance matrices for understanding SVM signal detectors.

name: ProfWeight
description: Transfer information from deep network to simpler model.

name: REFNE
description: Extracting symbolic rules from trained neural network ensembles.

name: RxREN
description: Reverse engineering neural networks for rule extraction.

name: SHAP
description: A unified approach to interpretting model predictions.

name: SIDU
description: Similarity, difference, and uniqueness input perturbation.

name: STA
description: Interpreting models via Single Tree Approximation.

name: Strumbelj, et. al.
description: Explanation of individual classifications using game theory.

name: SVM+P
description: Rule extraction from support vector machines.

name: Tolomei, et. al.
description: Interpretable predictions of tree-ensembles via actionable feature tweaking.

name: Tree Metrics
description: Making sense of a forest of trees.

name: TreeSHAP
description: Consistent feature attribute for tree ensembles.

name: TREPAN
description: Extracting tree-structured representations of trained networks.

name: X-TREPAN
description: Adapted etraction of comprehensible decision tree in ANNs.

name: Decision List
description: Like a decision tree with no branches.

name: Explainable Boosting Machine
description: Method that predicts based on learned vector graphs of features.

name: Naive Bayes
description: Good classification, poor estimation using conditional probabilities.

name: RuleFit
description: Sparse linear model as decision rules including feature interactions.

name: Attention is not Explanation
description: Authors perform a series of NLP experiments which argue attention does not provide meaningful explanations. They also demosntrate that different attentions can generate similar model outputs.

name: Attention is not --not-- Explanation
description: This is a rebutal to the above paper. Authors argue that multiple explanations can be valid and that the and that attention can produce a valid explanation, if not -the- valid explanation.

name: Do Not Trust Additive Explanations
description: Authors argue that addditive explanations (e.g. LIME, SHAP, Break Down) fail to take feature ineractions into account and are thus unreliable.

name: Please Stop Permuting Features An Explanation and Alternatives
description: Authors demonstrate why permuting features is misleading, especially where there is strong feature dependence. They offer several previously described alternatives.

name: Stop Explaining Black Box Machine Learning Models for High States Decisions and Use Interpretable Models Instead
description: Authors present a number of issues with explainable ML and challenges to interpretable ML: (1) constructing optimal logical models, (2) constructing optimal sparse scoring systems, (3) defining interpretability and creating methods for specific methods. They also offer an argument for why interpretable models might exist in many different domains.

name: The (Un)reliability of Saliency Methods
description: Authors demonstrate how saliency methods vary attribution when adding a constant shift to the input data. They argue that methods should fulfill input invariance, that a saliency method mirror the sensistivity of the model with respect to transformations of the input.

name: EthicalML/xai
description: A toolkit for XAI which is focused exclusively on tabular data. It implements a variety of data and model evaluation techniques.

name: PAIR-code/what-if-tool
description: A tool for Tensorboard or Notebooks which allows investigating model performance and fairness.

name: slundberg/shap
description: A Python module for using Shapley Additive Explanations.

name: Debate: Interpretability is necessary for ML
description: A debate on whether interpretability is necessary for ML with Rich Caruana and Patrice Simard for and Kilian Weinberger and Yann LeCun against.

name: The Institute for Ethical AI & Machine Learning
description: A UK-based research center that performs research into ethical AI/ML, which frequently involves XAI.

name: Tim Miller
description: One of the preeminent researchers in XAI.

name: Rich Caruana
description: The man behind Explainable Boosting Machines.
